awd_titl_txt: Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) National Communications Office (LNCO)
awd_abstract_narration:
The needs for science communication to diverse stakeholders are changing rapidly in an era of dramatic global change, shifting human demographic trends, and the widespread digital nature of communication and networking. This award supports a new and nimble Communications Office that will bring, to the Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) network, innovative capabilities to interact, share information, synthesize data, and collaborate in all areas of research, communication, and education both within and outside of the network. New programs and activities will encourage and promote diversity in education and training to enhance communication and outreach to the public; to local, regional, and federal agencies; and to non-governmental and non-profit agencies. The support services provided to the scientific community and to society will take full advantage of recent technological innovations that are informed by emerging socio-cultural insights to develop new strategies for effective communication and for enabling more creative collaborative research.

Project goals for communication and outreach are to cultivate relationships and synthetic team science within the LTER community, broaden engagements between the LTER community and other researchers and stakeholders outside the network, and disseminate LTER scientific discoveries and policy- and management-relevant knowledge to targeted audiences. The Communications Office will develop an effective and engaging web presence featuring online research fora, multi-media research highlights, and access to tools and services that build awareness and participation in the LTER Network. Partnerships with the Strategic Environmental Communications and Media Program at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management and with a new, state-of-the-art facility in environmental communications and media (Outreach, Communication, and Training for Ocean Science) will leverage sophisticated science communication and education resources. The Office will identify and deploy resources to maximize opportunities for synthesis across the LTER network. Synthesis working groups and distributed graduate seminars will be supported, with topics identified by the LTER and other research communities.  Additional networking will be supported through the triennial All Scientists' Meeting, annual meetings held in conjunction with other professional meetings, and promotion and enabling of virtual LTER network interactions and team science. The Communications Office will support LTER education and training using a combination of in-person and virtual training in science communication and environmental media, training in facilitating collaboration skills, and graduate/early-career training in open synthesis science. Through support and coordination of the LTER Education Committee, the Communications Office will serve as an information hub on topics such as best practices, evaluation metrics and tools for student tracking. It will help identify and cultivate new partners for LTER education and training efforts, and will encourage and promote diversity through collaboration with multiple societies and organizations that promote participation by under-served groups. All activities will be evaluated using contemporary formative and summative assessments, facilitating an adaptive approach to advancing communication, synthesis, and education across the LTER network.

por.por_cntn:
The LTER National Communications Office (renamed the LTER Network Office (LNO) in 2019) serves as a hub for synthesis research, education, communication and outreach activities of the National Science Foundation-funded Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) sites. Over the life of this grant (2015-2022), the LTER Network Office built a robust competitive awards program to support re-use of data generated by LTER sites and integration of LTER data with external data sources such as those generated by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), federal and state agencies such as the US Geological Survey (USGS), the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the Department of Energy (DOE), as well as the National Science Foundation?s Long Term Research in Environmental Biology program. 

 

The synthesis science generated through LNO working groups not only adds new value to the original investment in LTER science, it also fulfills the vision of an LTER Network that is greater than the sum of the individual parts. By integrating observations and experiments from multiple ecosystem types, LTER synthesis working groups can test how the mechanisms of ecosystem functioning discovered at specific sites apply in locations with different species, climates, and social-ecological contexts. 

 

For example, an analysis from the Global Patterns in Stream Energy and Nutrient Cycling working group assembled a global dataset of organic and inorganic forms of nitrogen from 2053 stream sites across temperate, boreal, desert, and Arctic biomes. They found that in streams with high concentrations of total nitrogen, the proportion of organic nitrogen was consistently low. This matters because the ratio of organic to inorganic nitrogen affects how organic matter in streams is recycled, and ultimately, the water quality in downstream lakes and estuaries.

 

Synthesis activities also generate combined datasets that are useful for developing, calibrating and testing ecosystem models, such as the SOils DAta Harmonization database (SoDaH), a collection of more than 360,000 soil samples spanning 400+ unique locations and five major research networks. Including modelers in the synthesis effort helped to identify the parameters that were both useful and available and resulted in new recommendations for field data collection, as well as a purpose-built database. The database includes datasets from experimental manipulations and related control sites and it continues to accept new data contributions and generate new analyses and insights.

 

In addition to funding and facilitating synthetic science, the LTER Network Office promotes cohesion across many diverse LTER sites and functions, organizing sub-communities of information managers, education specialists, site managers and investigators focused on particular themes where research professionals learn from one another, improve skills, and share resources.

 

Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Justice has been an important theme during this award and the Network Office has curated an extensive set of resources that are especially relevant for field ecologists and their students. The Network Office has also conducted or organized trainings for Network personnel in bystander intervention, developing effective codes of conduct, and mentorship.

 

LNO communication activities include an extensive website and document archive, a monthly newsletter, social media accounts, and photo archive. These channels raise awareness of LTER training and collaborative opportunities across the Network and also serve to connect LTER participants with the activities of related networks such as the Critical Zone Collaborative Network, the National Ecological Observatory Network, the Long Term Agroecosystem Network, Fluxnet, and the International Long Term Ecological Research Network, as well as many more ephemeral Research Coordination Networks (RCN). Overall, the LTER Network Office maintains institutional memory within the LTER Network and improves coordination among other major federal science investments.
